post_text: The Center School Art Show will be held April 9th through April 13th. An “Art Opening” for families will be held Monday, April 9th from 5:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. to provide an opportunity for your children to show their artwork on display throughout the building. In addition to our art show, the students from all grade levels have created an art installation in the front lobby.
text: The Center School Art Show will be held April 9th through April 13th. An “Art Opening” for families will be held Monday, April 9th from 5:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m. to provide an opportunity for your children to show their artwork on display throughout the building. In addition to our art show, the students from all grade levels have created an art installation in the front lobby.

post_text:
A "WONDERful event!"
To enhance our kindness and growth mindset initiatives at the Litchfield Intermediate School, the entire student body and staff attended a private showing of the movie Wonder at the Apple Cinemas in Barkamsted, CT, on Tuesday, November 21. The movie's message is an important one - be thankful for the gifts and friendships we all have. We would like to thank the Litchfield PTO for generously supporting this event.

A "WONDERful event!"

The movie's message is an important one - be thankful for the gifts and friendships we all have. We would like to thank the Litchfield PTO for generously supporting this event.

post_text:
Staff Professional Development Day:
On Tuesday, August 29th Center School Staff learned about the meaning of a Growth Mindset. Teachers participated in a group challenge that involved balloons and a Growth Mindset, teamwork, patience and GRIT. This year the staff at Center School looks forward to continuing their learning and reflection of a Growth Mindset with each other and our students and families.

post_text: This year the Center School community has partnered together to promote and recognize good character through the Character Education Program, Keys to Good Character. Throughout the school year Center School students have come together to collaborate and promote respect, trustworthiness, responsibility, empathy, fairness, and honesty. On Friday, May 26th, the students, staff and families of Center School came together to celebrate the hard work and achievements of our students at our Keys to Good Character Assembly.
text: This year the Center School community has partnered together to promote and recognize good character through the Character Education Program, Keys to Good Character. Throughout the school year Center School students have come together to collaborate and promote respect, trustworthiness, responsibility, empathy, fairness, and honesty. On Friday, May 26th, the students, staff and families of Center School came together to celebrate the hard work and achievements of our students at our Keys to Good Character Assembly.

post_text: On Saturday, May 6, 2017, students and families across our district came together for the annual Lighting Up Litchfield event. This year’s theme was Colors of Emotion. In preparation for this event, students decorated lanterns to represent various emotions they learned about, as well as how to cope with these emotions. Groups from Center School and Litchfield Intermediate School were led on a walk to Community Field by Litchfield High School’s AOK club students. Over $900 was raised for the Litchfield Public Schools mental health programs through this event.
text: On Saturday, May 6, 2017, students and families across our district came together for the annual Lighting Up Litchfield event. This year’s theme was Colors of Emotion. In preparation for this event, students decorated lanterns to represent various emotions they learned about, as well as how to cope with these emotions. Groups from Center School and Litchfield Intermediate School were led on a walk to Community Field by Litchfield High School’s AOK club students. Over $900 was raised for the Litchfield Public Schools mental health programs through this event.

post_text:
Center School’s Enrichment Academy

On Friday, May 19, 2017 Center School piloted its first ever enrichment academy. Center School Staff and parents facilitated engaging and collaborative workshops of various topics. Some of the workshops offered to students were led by Computer Scientist, professional chefs, lawyers, artisans, musicians and journalist just to name of few. Some of the featured workshops were: Breaker Space, Yoga, Intro to Spanish, Community Service, cooking, fitness, human body and movement, and mock trial.
text:
Center School’s Enrichment Academy

On Friday, May 19, 2017 Center School piloted its first ever enrichment academy. Center School Staff and parents facilitated engaging and collaborative workshops of various topics. Some of the workshops offered to students were led by Computer Scientist, professional chefs, lawyers, artisans, musicians and journalist just to name of few. Some of the featured workshops were: Breaker Space, Yoga, Intro to Spanish, Community Service, cooking, fitness, human body and movement, and mock trial.

post_text: The students at Center School enjoyed their last school-wide morning meeting to celebrate the key of Trustworthiness, some of the good choices that have been exhibited over the last two months were shared. The key of Fairness was introduced, the students will be working on that key for the remainder of the school year. At Center School we define Fairness as listening to others, not blaming others, playing by the rules and sharing/taking turns. Students are encouraged to show fairness at school, home and in their community.
text: The students at Center School enjoyed their last school-wide morning meeting to celebrate the key of Trustworthiness, some of the good choices that have been exhibited over the last two months were shared. The key of Fairness was introduced, the students will be working on that key for the remainder of the school year. At Center School we define Fairness as listening to others, not blaming others, playing by the rules and sharing/taking turns. Students are encouraged to show fairness at school, home and in their community.

post_text: "Congratulations to Alyssa DiLeone, a fifth grader at Litchfield Intermediate School, for being one of three winners of the Ridgefield Playhouse and Union Savings Bank's immigration essay contest. Alyssa wrote about her grandfather's immigration experience from Italy to the U.S. Each winning essayist received $50 and a very large candy bar! This field trip is a part of the Immigration Nation program, which is generously funded by EdAdvance."

post_text:
Center School Preschool will be accepting initial applications for the 2017-2018 Preschool Program for children living in Litchfield, Bantam, or Northfield. Openings are anticipated in the three-year-old and four-year-old sections.

Children must be 3 or 4 years of age on or before December 31, 2017.

For more information or to download an application, please visit www.litchfieldschools.org. Applications are due by February 17, 2017.

Children must be 3 or 4 years of age on or before December 31, 2017.

For more information or to download an application, please visit www.litchfieldschools.org. Applications are due by February 17, 2017.

post_text: On Thursday, February 2nd, the students at Center School were on the edge of their seat for an engaging performance by John Marshall, Mark Ingram, and physical education teacher Andy Parker. They performed percussion pieces that highlighted instruments from all over the world. Following the performance students participated in workshops exploring the African Djembe, Balafon techniques, Talking Drum, Udu Drums, and Egyptian Tambourine. The program and workshops were made possible through the generosity of the Center School PTO Cultural Enrichment program.

post_text: On Thursday night, members of the community celebrated achievements of many young artists from Center School and Litchfield Intermediate School at the annual art show exhibited in the gallery of the Oliver Wolcott Library. Selected works from grades Pre-K through 6 were on display, accompanied by light refreshments for the opening reception. Anyone who was not able to attend the reception may still view the artwork at the Oliver Wolcott Library, which will be on display until Monday, February 13.

post_text:
Dear Families,

Litchfield Center School is gearing up to launch the first of its series of workshops as part of the "Ready, Set, Grow" program. This program aims to welcome incoming Kindergarten students and their families as they explore activities that resemble the upcoming work and academic expectations of Kindergarten as well as to provide resources and tips for supporting skills at home. The program will begin with a Parent Information Night on Monday, February 6th at 6:30 at LCS. Please visit the Center School web page for details about registration for this event.

post_text:
Center School Preschool is offering informational and interactive sessions for families interested in our preschool program for the 2017-2018 school year. Session 1 is an informational session for parents about our three-year-old, four-year-old, and extended day preschool sessions and will be held on January 23, 2017 at 6:00 p.m. (snow date January 24) in the Center School Gymnasium. Session 2 is an interactive session for parents and children where preschoolers can see the classrooms, meet the teachers, and participate in preschool activities. Session 2 takes place on January 30 at 6:00 p.m. (snow date January 31) in the Center School preschool classrooms. For more information or to rsvp to one or both of these events, please visit www.litchfieldschools.org
and click on the Way to Grow tab on the Center School page.

The McCormick Mile

Annual LIS tradition since 2010, always on the Tuesday before Thanksgiving

Students/staff run, walk, jog, dance 1 mile together, then enjoy apples

In honor of JoAnne McCormick, former LIS nurse who passed away from pancreatic cancer in 2010

Way to celebrate healthy lifestyle of exercising and good nutrition

post_text:
The KEYS to Good Character is a character education program that is being implemented at Center School. The students and staff at Center School work together as a community to promote the KEYS to Good Character. The KEYS to Good Character are: Respect, Responsibility, Empathy, Trustworthiness and Fairness. Each month a different KEY will be recognized. When students exhibit that particular character trait they will earn a “KEY” at school and this “KEY” will be placed on one of our KEYS to Good Character bulletin boards. For the combined months of November/December we will be working on the character KEY of Responsibility. At Center School we define Responsibility as: always doing your best, thinking before you act, using appropriate behavior, and taking ownership of your learning.

As part of our Character Education program, we would also like to recognize good character at home and in the community. Parents are encouraged to send a note to school letting us know when their child exhibits responsibility at home or in the community and they are awarded a “KEY” here at school.
text:

The KEYS to Good Character are: Respect, Responsibility, Empathy, Trustworthiness and Fairness. Each month a different KEY will be recognized. When students exhibit that particular character trait they will earn a “KEY” at school and this “KEY” will be placed on one of our KEYS to Good Character bulletin boards. For the combined months of November/December we will be working on the character KEY of Responsibility. At Center School we define Responsibility as: always doing your best, thinking before you act, using appropriate behavior, and taking ownership of your learning.

As part of our Character Education program, we would also like to recognize good character at home and in the community. Parents are encouraged to send a note to school letting us know when their child exhibits responsibility at home or in the community and they are awarded a “KEY” here at school.
